enterprise.word_definition: an organization created for business ventures
enterprise.word_example: Thereby it restored confidence and hope in the American people, it freed and stimulated  enterprise, it restored the Government to its position as an umpire instead of a player in the economic game.

adherence.word_definition: faithful support for a cause or political party or religion
adherence.word_example: By  adherence to the principles of decentralization, self-government, ordered liberty, and opportunity and freedom to the individual our American experiment has yielded a degree of well-being unparalleled in all the world.

contribution.word_definition: the part played by a person in bringing about a result
contribution.word_example: But in addition to this great record of  contributions of the Republican Party to progress, there has been a further fundamental  contribution — a  contribution perhaps more important than all the others — and that is the resistance of the Republican Party to every attempt to inject the Government into business in competition with its citizens.

unparalleled.word_example: The acceptance of these ideas meant the destruction of self-government through centralization of government; it meant the undermining of initiative and enterprise upon which our people have grown to  unparalleled greatness.

Herbert Hoover on \"Rugged Individualism.list_detailed_description: The son of a blacksmith, Herbert Hoover earned millions through his work as a geologist and mining engineer. While his economic successes led to political positions, he believed that American progress is rooted in the separation of government and business. Here are some words from the October 22, 1928 speech that capped his campaign to become the 31st President.

President Obama's Commencement Address 2.list_brief_description: President Obama gave the commencement address at Rutgers University in New Jersey this year on May 15, 2016. The speech addressed how the country has confronted...

hallmark.word_definition: a mark on an article of trade to indicate its origin
hallmark.word_example: But because of dreamers and innovators and strivers and activists, progress has been this nation’s  hallmark.

unencumbered.word_definition: free of anything that impedes or is burdensome
unencumbered.word_example: ...it’s just made us more confident in our ignorance. We assume whatever is on the web must be true. We search for sites that just reinforce our own predispositions. Opinions masquerade as facts.

contentious.word_example: Progress in America has been hard and  contentious, and sometimes bloody.

cynicism.word_example: Cynicism is so easy, and cynics don’t accomplish much.

epidemic.word_definition: a widespread outbreak of an infectious disease
epidemic.word_example: When developing countries don’t have functioning health systems,  epidemics like Zika or Ebola can spread and threaten Americans, too. And a wall won't stop that.

arc.word_definition: a continuous portion of a circle
arc.word_example: But those are sporadic, those moments, those episodes.

elitist.word_definition: someone who believes in rule by a high-status group
elitist.word_example: ... But when our leaders express a disdain for facts, when they’re not held accountable for repeating falsehoods and just making stuff up, while actual experts are dismissed as  elitists, then we’ve got a problem.

sporadic.word_definition: recurring in scattered or unpredictable instances
sporadic.word_example: But those are  sporadic, those moments, those episodes.

charismatic.word_definition: possessing an extraordinary ability to attract
charismatic.word_example: They didn’t happen because some  charismatic leader got everybody suddenly to agree on everything.

hone.word_definition: refine or make more perfect or effective
hone.word_example: And by doing so, you’ll strengthen your own position, and you’ll  hone your arguments.

inflection.word_definition: deviation from a straight or normal course
inflection.word_example: It depends on us, on the choices we make, particularly at certain  inflection points in history; particularly when big changes are happening and everything seems up for grabs.

brunt.word_definition: the main part, especially of a force or shock
brunt.word_example: If we don’t act, if we don't follow through on the progress we made in Paris, the progress we've been making here at home, your generation will feel the  brunt of this catastrophe.

nihilism.word_definition: complete denial of established authority and institutions
nihilism.word_example: When overseas states start falling apart, they become breeding grounds for terrorists and ideologies of  nihilism and despair that ultimately can reach our shores. When developing countries don’t have functioning health systems, epidemics like Zika or Ebola can spread and threaten Americans, too.

beneficiary.word_definition: the recipient of funds or other advantages
beneficiary.word_example: We are  beneficiaries of the labor and the grit and the courage of generations who came before.

globalization.word_example: ... global supply chains, and cargo ships that crisscross oceans, and online commerce that can render borders obsolete. And a lot of folks have legitimate concerns with the way  globalization has progressed -- that's one of the changes that's been taking place -- jobs shipped overseas, trade deals that sometimes put workers and businesses at a disadvantage.

loophole.word_definition: an ambiguity that makes it possible to evade an obligation
loophole.word_example: And just as America is better, the world is better than when I graduated. Since I graduated, an Iron Curtain fell, apartheid ended. There’s more democracy. We virtually eliminated certain diseases like polio. We’ve cut extreme poverty drastically. We've cut infant mortality by an enormous amount.

disproportionate.word_example: Yes, special interests and lobbyists have  disproportionate access to the corridors of power.

discerning.word_definition: having or revealing keen insight and good judgment
discerning.word_example: ...we have access to more information than at any time in human history, at a touch of a button. But, ironically, the flood of information hasn’t made us more  discerning of the truth. In some ways, it’s just made us more confident in our ignorance. We assume whatever is on the web must be true.

lobbyist.word_definition: someone who is employed to persuade how legislators vote
lobbyist.word_example: Yes, special interests and  lobbyists have disproportionate access to the corridors of power.

disparaging.word_example: Building walls won't do that. It won't boost our economy, and it won’t enhance our security either. Isolating or  disparaging Muslims, suggesting that they should be treated differently when it comes to entering this country -- that is not just a betrayal of our values...

inertia.word_definition: the tendency of something to stay in rest or motion
inertia.word_example: You’ll look at things with fresher eyes, unencumbered by the biases and blind spots and  inertia and general crankiness of your parents and grandparents and old heads like me.

predisposition.word_definition: an inclination to interpret statements in a particular way
predisposition.word_example: We assume whatever is on the web must be true. We search for sites that just reinforce our own  predispositions. Opinions masquerade as facts. The wildest conspiracy theories are taken for gospel.

embedded.word_definition: enclosed firmly in a surrounding mass
embedded.word_example: ...escape superstition, and sectarianism, and tribalism, and no-nothingness. They believed in rational thought and experimentation, and the capacity of informed citizens to master our own fates. That is  embedded in our constitutional design. That spirit informed our inventors and our explorers, the Edisons and the Wright Brothers, and the George Washington Carvers and the Grace Hoppers...

prioritize.word_definition: assign a status in order of importance or urgency
prioritize.word_example: It determines what policies they  prioritize.

bias.word_definition: a partiality preventing objective consideration of an issue
bias.word_example: You’ll look at things with fresher eyes, unencumbered by the  biases and blind spots and inertia and general crankiness of your parents and grandparents and old heads like me.

apartheid.word_definition: a social policy of racial segregation
apartheid.word_example: And just as America is better, the world is better than when I graduated. Since I graduated, an Iron Curtain fell,  apartheid ended. There’s more democracy. We virtually eliminated certain diseases like polio. We’ve cut extreme poverty drastically. We've cut infant mortality by an enormous amount..

skepticism.word_definition: doubt about the truth of something
skepticism.word_example: You have a healthy  skepticism for conventional wisdom.

President Obama's Commencement Address 2.list_detailed_description: President Obama gave the commencement address at Rutgers University in New Jersey this year on May 15, 2016. The speech addressed how the country has confronted our political problems with the intelligence we have derived from our educations, which will help us tell the difference between lofty promises with nothing behind them and vows we can keep. Here are twenty seven vocabulary words from President Obama's address.

Michelle Obama's final address as First.list_brief_description: On January 6, 2017, in celebration of the National School Counselor of the Year, Michelle Obama gave some words she hopes young Americans will always remember....

affordable.word_example: We are also very proud of all that this administration has done to make higher education more  affordable.

daunting.word_example: Because as a nation, that’s where the spotlight should also be — on kids who work hard in school and do the right thing when no one is watching, many beating  daunting odds.

inspire.word_definition: spur on or encourage especially by cheers and shouts
inspire.word_example: The hope that when people see us for who we truly are, maybe, just maybe they, too, will be  inspired to rise to their best possible selves.

engaged.word_definition: having one's attention or mind or energy consumed
engaged.word_example: You need to prepare yourself to be informed and  engaged as a citizen, to serve and to lead, to stand up for our proud American values and to honor them in your daily lives.

obstacle.word_definition: something that stands in the way and must be surmounted
obstacle.word_example: And when you encounter  obstacles — because I guarantee you, you will, and many of you already have — when you are struggling and you start thinking about giving up, I want you to remember something that my husband and I have talked about since we first started this journey nearly a decade ago, something that has carried us through every moment in this White House and every moment of our lives, and that is the power of hope

promise.word_definition: grounds for feeling hopeful about the future
promise.word_example: You see the  promise in each of your students. You believe in them even when they can’t believe in themselves, and you work tirelessly to help them be who they were truly meant to be.

financial.word_example: In fact, a recent study showed that students who met with a school counselor to talk about  financial aid or college were three times more likely to attend college, and they were nearly seven times more likely to apply for  financial aid.

phenomenal.word_example: We wanted everyone to know about the difference that these  phenomenal men and women have been making in the lives of our young people every day.

support.word_example: Next, we launched Better Make Room. It’s a social media campaign to give young people the  support and inspiration they need to actually complete higher education.

priority.word_definition: status established in order of importance or urgency
priority.word_example: Because let’s be honest, if we’re always shining the spotlight on professional athletes or recording artists or Hollywood celebrities, if those are the only achievements we celebrate, then why would we ever think kids would see college as a  priority?

critical.word_definition: characterized by careful evaluation and judgment
critical.word_example: And that means getting the best education possible so you can think critically, so you can express yourself clearly, so you can get a good job and support yourself and your family, so you can be a positive force in your communities.

role.word_definition: the actions and activities assigned to a person or group
role.word_example: And we know that school counselors like all of the folks standing with me on this stage have played a critical  role in helping us get there.

preserve.word_definition: keep in safety and protect from harm, loss, or destruction
preserve.word_example: Just like generations who have come before you, you have to do your part to  preserve and protect those freedoms.

diversity.word_example: If you are a person of faith, know that religious  diversity is a great American tradition, too.

compassion.word_definition: a deep awareness of and sympathy for another's suffering
compassion.word_example: And whether you are Muslim, Christian, Jewish, Hindu, Sikh — these religions are teaching our young people about justice, and  compassion, and honesty.

empower.word_example: Empower yourselves with a good education, then get out there and use that education to build a country worthy of your boundless promise.

infusion.word_definition: the act of introducing a modifying element or quality
infusion.word_example: If you or your parents are immigrants, know that you are part of a proud American tradition — the  infusion of new cultures, talents and ideas, generation after generation, that has made us the greatest country on earth.

possible.word_example: But with a lot of hard work and a good education, anything is  possible — even becoming President.

background.word_definition: a person's social heritage, previous experience, or training
background.word_example: So for all the young people in this room and those who are watching, know that this country belongs to you — to all of you, from every  background and walk of life.

dedication.word_example: And I am so grateful to all of you for your passion and your  dedication and all the hard work on behalf of our next generation.

overwhelming.word_example: And you do it all in the face of some  overwhelming challenges — tight budgets, impossible student- counselor ratios — yeah, amen — endless demands on your time.

achievement.word_example: We wanted to focus that same level of energy and attention on kids going to college because of their academic  achievements.

earn.word_definition: acquire or deserve by one's efforts or actions
earn.word_example: But I also want to be very clear: This right isn’t just handed to you. No, this right has to be  earned every single day.

anxious.word_definition: causing or fraught with or showing anxiety
anxious.word_example: You stick with students in their darkest moments, when they’re most  anxious and afraid.

matter.word_example: These men and women show them that those kids  matter; that they have something to offer; that no  matter where they’re from or how much money their parents have, no  matter what they look like or who they love or how they worship or what language they speak at home, they have a place in this country.

mimic.word_example: We wanted to  mimic all the drama and excitement traditionally reserved for those few amazing football and basketball players choosing their college and university teams.

determined.word_definition: characterized by great firmness of purpose
determined.word_example: So don’t be afraid — you hear me, young people? Don’t be afraid. Be focused. Be  determined.

fundamental.word_example: It is our  fundamental belief in the power of hope that has allowed us to rise above the voices of doubt and division, of anger and fear that we have faced in our own lives and in the life of this country.

counselor.word_definition: someone who gives advice about problems
counselor.word_example: So our school  counselors are truly among the heroes of the Reach Higher story.

glorious.word_example: You see, our  glorious diversity — our diversities of faiths and colors and creeds — that is not a threat to who we are, it makes us who we are.

Michelle Obama's final address as First.list_detailed_description: On January 6, 2017, in celebration of the National School Counselor of the Year, Michelle Obama gave some words she hopes young Americans will always remember.

History is made in PA: Clinton's DNC Acc.list_brief_description: Hillary Clinton became the first woman to act as a major party's presidential nominee on July 28, 2016. Her speech was personal and political, both critical of ...

bigotry.word_definition: the intolerance and prejudice of a bigot
bigotry.word_example: So enough with the  bigotry and bombast.

provocation.word_definition: a means of arousing or stirring to action
provocation.word_example: Donald Trump can't even handle the rough-and-tumble of a presidential campaign.  He loses his cool at the slightest  provocation.

campaign.word_definition: related operations aimed at achieving a particular goal
campaign.word_example: And to those of you who joined our  campaign this week.  And what a remarkable week it's been.

mobility.word_example: There's too much inequality. Too little social  mobility.

dynamic.word_definition: characterized by action or forcefulness of personality
dynamic.word_example: But just look at the strengths we bring to meet these challenges. We have the most  dynamic and diverse people in the world. We have the most tolerant and generous young people we've ever had.

commitment.word_definition: the act of binding yourself to a course of action
commitment.word_example: We heard from our terrific vice president, the one-and-only Joe Biden, who spoke from his big heart about our party's  commitment to working people.

community.word_definition: a group of people living in a particular local area
community.word_example: David Brown asked the  community to support his force, maybe even join them.

immigrant.word_definition: a person who comes to a country in order to settle there
immigrant.word_example: And we'll build a path to citizenship for millions of  immigrants who are already contributing to our economy!

entrepreneur.word_definition: someone who organizes a business venture

systemic.word_example: So let's put ourselves in the shoes of young black and Latino men and women who face the effects of  systemic racism, and are made to feel like their lives are disposable.

innovative.word_definition: being like nothing done or experienced or created before

citizenship.word_definition: membership in a state with rights and duties
citizenship.word_example: And we'll build a path to  citizenship for millions of immigrants who are already contributing to our economy!

ravaged.word_definition: having been robbed and destroyed by force and violence
ravaged.word_example: From communities  ravaged by addiction to regions hollowed out by plant closures.

trump.word_example: A country where all our children can dream, and those dreams are within reach. Where families are strong… communities are safe…  And yes, love  trumps hate.

justice.word_definition: the quality of being just or fair
justice.word_example: You've put economic and social  justice issues front and center, where they belong.

deserve.word_example: When there are no ceilings, the sky's the limit.  So let's keep going, until every one of the 161 million women and girls across America has the opportunity she  deserves.

motivate.word_example: In this campaign, I've met so many people who  motivate me to keep fighting for change.  And, with your help, I will carry all of your voices and stories with me to the White House.

disability.word_definition: when one cannot perform due to physical or mental unfitness
disability.word_example: I went to work for the Children's Defense Fund, going door-to-door in New Bedford, Massachusetts on behalf of children with  disabilities who were denied the chance to go to school.

racism.word_definition: the prejudice that one people are superior to another
racism.word_example: So let's put ourselves in the shoes of young black and Latino men and women who face the effects of systemic  racism, and are made to feel like their lives are disposable.

contributing.word_definition: tending to bring about; being partly responsible for
contributing.word_example: And we'll build a path to citizenship for millions of immigrants who are already  contributing to our economy!

self-control.word_example: She said that what worried President Kennedy during that very dangerous time was that a war might be started – not by big men with  self-control and restraint, but by little men – the ones moved by fear and pride.

frustrated.word_example: Some of you are  frustrated – even furious.

thrive.word_example: I believe America  thrives when the middle class  thrives.

economy.word_definition: the system of production and distribution and consumption
economy.word_example: Now we are clear-eyed about what our country is up against. But we are not afraid. We will rise to the challenge, just as we always have. We will not build a wall. Instead, we will build an  economy where everyone who wants a good paying job can get one.

affordable.word_example: If you believe that every man, woman, and child in America has the right to  affordable health care…join us. If you believe that we should say “no” to unfair trade deals... that we should stand up to China... that we should support our steelworkers and autoworkers and homegrown manufacturers…join us.

bombast.word_definition: pompous or pretentious talk or writing
bombast.word_example: So enough with the bigotry and  bombast.

bully.word_definition: discourage or frighten with threats or a domineering manner
bully.word_example: When I tried to hide from a neighborhood  bully, she literally blocked the door.

infrastructure.word_definition: the basic features of a system or organization
infrastructure.word_example: In my first 100 days, we will work with both parties to pass the biggest investment in new, good-paying jobs since World War II.  Jobs in manufacturing, clean energy, technology and innovation, small business, and  infrastructure.

empower.word_definition: give or delegate power or authority to
empower.word_example: So I want to tell you tonight how we will  empower Americans to live better lives.

disposable.word_definition: an item that can be thrown away after it has been used
disposable.word_example: So let's put ourselves in the shoes of young black and Latino men and women who face the effects of systemic racism, and are made to feel like their lives are  disposable.

immigration.word_definition: movement of persons into a place
immigration.word_example: Comprehensive  immigration reform will grow our economy and keep families together - and it's the right thing to do.

podium.word_definition: a platform raised above the surrounding level
podium.word_example: Now, sometimes the people at this  podium are new to the national stage.

enduring.word_example: Our Founders embraced the  enduring truth that we are stronger together.

milestone.word_definition: stone post at side of a road to show distances
milestone.word_example: Tonight, we've reached a  milestone in our nation's march toward a more perfect union:  the first time that a major party has nominated a woman for President.

selfless.word_definition: showing concern for the welfare of others
selfless.word_example: They were drawn together by love of country and the  selfless passion to build something better for all who follow. That is the story of America.

motto.word_definition: a favorite saying of a sect or political group
motto.word_example: Our country's  motto is e pluribus unum: out of many, we are one.

spouse.word_example: Let's put ourselves in the shoes of police officers, kissing their kids and  spouses goodbye every day and heading off to do a dangerous and necessary job.

closure.word_example: From communities ravaged by addiction to regions hollowed out by plant  closures.

slogan.word_definition: a favorite saying of a sect or political group
slogan.word_example: It's not just a  slogan for our campaign.

turbulence.word_example: Anyone reading the news can see the threats and  turbulence we face.

divisive.word_example: And we will stand up against mean and  divisive rhetoric wherever it comes from.

inhumane.word_definition: reflecting a lack of pity or compassion
inhumane.word_example: I believe that when we have millions of hardworking immigrants contributing to our economy, it would be self-defeating and  inhumane to kick them out.

paralysis.word_definition: loss of the ability to move a body part

mimic.word_example: Or when he mocks and  mimics a reporter with a disability.

inequality.word_definition: lack of balance or similarity in status
inequality.word_example: There's too much  inequality. Too little social mobility.

unruly.word_definition: unable to be governed or controlled
unruly.word_example: When representatives from 13  unruly colonies met just down the road from here, some wanted to stick with the King.

radicalize.word_definition: make more extreme in social or political outlook
radicalize.word_example: We will disrupt their efforts online to reach and  radicalize young people in our country. It won't be easy or quick, but make no mistake – we will prevail.

entertainer.word_definition: a person who tries to please or amuse
entertainer.word_example: You know, for the past year, many people made the mistake of laughing off Donald Trump's comments – excusing him as an  entertainer just putting on a show.

addiction.word_example: From communities ravaged by  addiction to regions hollowed out by plant closures.

agenda.word_definition: a list of matters to be taken up, as at a meeting
agenda.word_example: A bold  agenda to improve the lives of people across our country - to keep you safe, to get you good jobs, and to give your kids the opportunities they deserve.

History is made in PA: Clinton's DNC Acc.list_detailed_description: Hillary Clinton became the first woman to act as a major party's presidential nominee on July 28, 2016. Her speech was personal and political, both critical of her opponent and a case for why people should vote for her and not against someone else. Here are 50 words from Clinton's acceptance speech.

President T. Roosevelt on \"The Man with.list_brief_description: Learn these words from Roosevelt's April 14, 1906 speech that calls the press to treat its subjects with objective moderation. During his two terms in office, T...

discontent.word_definition: a longing for something better than the present situation
discontent.word_example: On the other hand, the wild preachers of unrest and  discontent, the wild agitators against the entire existing order, the men who act crookedly, whether because of sinister design or from mere puzzle headedness, the men who preach destruction without proposing any substitute for what they intend to destroy, or who propose a substitute which would be far worse than the existing evils—all these men are the most dangerous opponents of real reform.

cynical.word_definition: believing the worst of human nature and motives
cynical.word_example: There results a general attitude either of  cynical belief in and indifference to public corruption or else of a distrustful inability to discriminate between the good and the bad.

agitation.word_example: So far as this movement of  agitation throughout the country takes the form of a fierce discontent with evil, of a determination to punish the authors of evil, whether in industry or politics, the feeling is to be heartily welcomed as a sign of healthy life.

generalization.word_definition: an idea or conclusion having broad application
generalization.word_example: To assail the great and admitted evils of our political and industrial life with such crude and sweeping  generalizations as to include decent men in the general condemnation means the searing of the public conscience.

sympathy.word_definition: sharing the feelings of others, especially sorrow or anguish
sympathy.word_example: More important than aught else is the development of the broadest  sympathy of man for man.

welfare.word_definition: a contented state of being happy and healthy and prosperous
welfare.word_example: The  welfare of the wage worker, the  welfare of the tiller of the soil, upon these depend the  welfare of the entire country; their good is not to be sought in pulling down others; but their good must be the prime object of all our statesmanship.

corrupt.word_definition: not straight; dishonest or immoral or evasive
corrupt.word_example: At the risk of repetition let me say again that my plea is not for immunity to, but for the most unsparing exposure of, the politician who betrays his trust, of the big business man who makes or spends his fortune in illegitimate or  corrupt ways.

provoke.word_definition: call forth, as an emotion, feeling, or response
provoke.word_example: If they fail to get their way they will still do incalculable harm by  provoking the kind of reaction which in its revolt against the senseless evil of their teaching would enthrone more securely than ever the evils which their misguided followers believe they are attacking.

disinterested.word_definition: unaffected by concern for one's own welfare
disinterested.word_example: There is any amount of good in the world, and there never was a time when loftier and more  disinterested work for the betterment of mankind was being done than now.

filth.word_definition: any substance considered disgustingly foul or unpleasant
filth.word_example: In Bunyan's "Pilgrim's Progress" you may recall the description of the Man with the Muck Rake, the man who could look no way but downward, with the muck rake in his hand; who was offered a celestial crown for his muck rake, but who would neither look up nor regard the crown he was offered, but continued to rake to himself the  filth of the floor.

unscrupulous.word_example: One of the chief counts against those who make indiscriminate assault upon men in business or men in public life is that they invite a reaction which is sure to tell powerfully in favor of the  unscrupulous scoundrel who really ought to be attacked, who ought to be exposed, who ought, if possible, to be put in the penitentiary.

service.word_definition: work done by one person or group that benefits another
service.word_example: There is filth on the floor, and it must be scraped up with the muck rake; and there are times and places where this  service is the most needed of all the  services that can be performed.

indispensable.word_example: The men with the muck rakes are often  indispensable to the well being of society; but only if they know when to stop raking the muck, and to look upward to the celestial crown above them, to the crown of worthy endeavor.

zealot.word_definition: a fervent and even militant proponent of something
zealot.word_example: But in addition to honesty, we need sanity. No honesty will make a public man useful if that man is timid or foolish, if he is a hot-headed  zealot or an impracticable visionary.

endorsement.word_example: Some persons are sincerely incapable of understanding that to denounce mud slinging does not mean the  endorsement of whitewashing; and both the interested individuals who need whitewashing and those others who practice mud slinging like to encourage such confusion of ideas.

vile.word_example: Now, it is very necessary that we should not flinch from seeing what is  vile and debasing.

condone.word_definition: excuse, overlook, or make allowances for
condone.word_example: We can no more and no less afford to  condone evil in the man of capital than evil in the man of no capital.

reckless.word_definition: marked by defiant disregard for danger or consequences
reckless.word_example: Gross and  reckless assaults on character, whether on the stump or in newspaper, magazine, or book, create a morbid and vicious public sentiment, and at the same time act as a profound deterrent to able men of normal sensitiveness and tend to prevent them from entering the public service at any price.

lurid.word_definition: glaringly vivid and graphic; marked by sensationalism
lurid.word_example: Expose the crime, and hunt down the criminal; but remember that even in the case of crime, if it is attacked in sensational,  lurid, and untruthful fashion, the attack may do more damage to the public mind than the crime itself.

sobriety.word_example: The men who with stern  sobriety and truth assail the many evils of our time, whether in the public press, or in magazines, or in books, are the leaders and allies of all engaged in the work for social and political betterment.

exaggeration.word_example: It puts a premium upon knavery untruthfully to attack an honest man, or even with hysterical  exaggeration to assail a bad man with untruth.

acquiescence.word_example: Bad though a state of hysterical excitement is, and evil though the results are which come from the violent oscillations such excitement invariably produces, yet a sodden  acquiescence in evil is even worse.

denounce.word_example: No good whatever will come from that warped and mock morality which  denounces the misdeeds of men of wealth and forgets the misdeeds practiced at their expense; which  denounces bribery, but blinds itself to blackmail; which foams with rage if a corporation secures favors by improper methods, and merely leers with hideous mirth if the corporation is itself wronged.

poise.word_definition: a state of being balanced in a stable equilibrium
poise.word_example: This truth should be kept constantly in mind by every free people desiring to preserve the sanity and  poise indispensable to the permanent success of self-government.

distinction.word_definition: a discrimination between things as different
distinction.word_example: If the whole picture is painted black there remains no hue whereby to single out the rascals for  distinction from their fellows.

potent.word_definition: having or wielding force or authority
potent.word_example: But the man who never does anything else, who never thinks or speaks or writes, save of his feats with the muck rake, speedily becomes, not a help but one of the most  potent forces for evil.

excess.word_definition: immoderation from going beyond sufficient limits
excess.word_example: Any  excess is almost sure to invite a reaction; and, unfortunately, the reactions instead of taking the form of punishment of those guilty of the  excess, is apt to take the form either of punishment of the unoffending or of giving immunity, and even strength, to offenders.

assail.word_example: The soul of every scoundrel is gladdened whenever an honest man is  assailed, or even when a scoundrel is untruthfully  assailed.

exposure.word_example: There should be relentless  exposure of and attack upon every evil man, whether politician or business man, every evil practice, whether in politics, business, or social life.

generosity.word_definition: the trait of being willing to give your money or time
generosity.word_example: The forces that tend for evil are great and terrible, but the forces of truth and love and courage and honesty and  generosity and sympathy are also stronger than ever before.

merciless.word_example: I hail as a benefactor every writer or speaker, every man who, on the platform or in a book, magazine, or newspaper, with  merciless severity makes such attack, provided always that he in his turn remembers that the attack is of use only if it is absolutely truthful.

praise.word_example: If Aristides is  praised overmuch as just, people get tired of hearing it; and over-censure of the unjust finally and from similar reasons results in their favor.

mendacity.word_example: The liar is no whit better than the thief, and if his  mendacity takes the form of slander he may be worse than most thieves.

virtue.word_example: But if they give good reason for distrust of what they say, if they chill the ardor of those who demand truth as a primary  virtue, they thereby betray the good cause and play into the hands of the very men against whom they are nominally at war.

President T. Roosevelt on \"The Man with.list_detailed_description: Learn these words from Roosevelt's April 14, 1906 speech that calls the press to treat its subjects with objective moderation. During his two terms in office, Theodore Roosevelt made the White House the center of news every day, which he facilitated by giving reporters a special room. Coverage was mostly favorable, but when Joseph Pulitzer published accusations of misconduct in the building of the Panama Canal, the President tried to charge him with libel.

renown.word_example: When I started writing songs as a teenager, and even as I started to achieve some  renown for my abilities, my aspirations for these songs only went so far.

dramatist.word_example: I would reckon he thought of himself as a  dramatist.

intolerance.word_example: And let us reflect that, having banished from our land that religious  intolerance under which mankind so long bled and suffered, we have yet gained little if we countenance a political  intolerance as despotic, as wicked, and capable of as bitter and bloody persecutions.

conflicting.word_example: To you, then, gentlemen, who are charged with the sovereign functions of legislation, and to those associated with you, I look with encouragement for that guidance and support which may enable us to steer with safety the vessel in which we are all embarked amidst the  conflicting elements of a troubled world.

diffusion.word_example: the  diffusion of information and arraignment of all abuses at the bar of the public reason

constitutional.word_definition: sanctioned by or consistent with or operating under the law

opinion.word_example: We are all Republicans, we are all Federalists. If there be any among us who would wish to dissolve this Union or to change its republican form, let them stand undisturbed as monuments of the safety with which error of  opinion may be tolerated where reason is left free to combat it.

touchstone.word_example: They should be the creed of our political faith, the text of civic instruction, the  touchstone by which to try the services of those we trust; and should we wander from them in moments of error or of alarm, let us hasten to retrace our steps and to regain the road which alone leads to peace, liberty, and safety.

Thomas Jefferson's First Inaugural Addre.list_detailed_description: 1800 was a bitter election year. The incumbent Federalist president ran against his Democratic-Republican vice-president. John Adams lost, but two rival candidates tied. The House of Representatives decided that Aaron Burr would get the secondary title. On March 4, 1801, in the new capital of Washington D.C., Thomas Jefferson was sworn in as the third president. Here are some of his words urging reconciliation.

Graduation Gems, 2016.list_brief_description: Not sure what to pack on your journey to a new life? Consider these pearls of wisdom from 2016 commencement speakers, and learn more about the themes of this ye...

gratitude.word_definition: a feeling of thankfulness and appreciation
gratitude.word_example: Finding  gratitude and appreciation is key to resilience. People who take the time to list things they are grateful for are happier and healthier. It turns out that counting your blessings can actually increase your blessings.

impact.word_definition: a forceful consequence; a strong effect
impact.word_example: But the message is that if you want to have a deep  impact on what matters to you, don’t do things at remove. Invest yourself fully. Get close.

intuition.word_definition: instinctive knowing, without the use of rational processes
intuition.word_example: And I want to be clear that your  intuition is different from your conscience. They work in tandem, but here’s the distinction: Your conscience shouts, ‘here’s what you should do,’ while your  intuition whispers, ‘here’s what you could do.’ Listen to that voice that tells you what you could do. Nothing will define your character more than that.

engage.word_definition: consume all of one's attention or time
engage.word_example: Turn towards the problems that you see. And  engage with them. Walk right up to them, look them in the eye ... then look yourself in the eye and decide what you’re going to do about them. In my experience, there’s just no substitute for actually going and seeing things.

advantage.word_definition: benefit resulting from some event or action
advantage.word_example: Now's the time to seize the day, take  advantage of this unique moment in history, and build bridges amongst us. Talking about gender, race, religion, and nations, not walls. Let us build bridges of love, versus walls of hate.

capable.word_definition: having the skills and qualifications to do things well
capable.word_example: So the question I asked when life told me no was, “What am I  capable of? Am I  capable of doing what I want to do?”

unencumbered.word_definition: free of anything that impedes or is burdensome
unencumbered.word_example: You’ll look at things with fresher eyes,  unencumbered by the biases and blind spots and inertia and general crankiness of your parents and grandparents and old heads like me.

ignorance.word_definition: the lack of knowledge or education
ignorance.word_example: At this moment in your life you know fewer limits, fewer taboos and fewer fears than you will ever in the future. So do not squander your  ignorance. Go out and do what your teachers and parents thought could not be done -- and what they never thought of doing.

prosperity.word_definition: a state of growth with rising profits and full employment
prosperity.word_example: So all of us need to do much more to build relationships with partners overseas, to deliver assistance to families and communities abroad, to promote stability worldwide. And we need to do this not because it is morally right, which it is; not just because it’s in keeping with our national ethos, which is also true; but because our own security and  prosperity demand it.

distinguish.word_example: The history we know, the stories we tell ourselves, relieve that existential anxiety, allow us to live beyond our fleeting lifespans, and permit us to value and love and  distinguish what is important. And the practice of history, both personal and professional, becomes a kind of conscience for us.

adversity.word_definition: a state of misfortune or affliction
adversity.word_example: You should never view your challenges as a disadvantage. Instead, it’s important for you to understand that your experience facing and overcoming  adversity is actually one of your biggest advantages.

cherish.word_example: The ‘uh-oh’ moments are worth  cherishing just as much as ‘ah-ha’ moments: Mistakes, failures, embarrassments and disappointments are a necessary component of growing wise. We can learn more from our not-so-good experiences than we can learn from our good ones.

reverberate.word_definition: have a long or continuing effect
reverberate.word_example: This act of choosing—the stories we tell versus the stories we leave out—will  reverberate across the rest of your life.

opportunity.word_definition: a possibility from a favorable combination of circumstances
opportunity.word_example: Look, if you take the unexpected  opportunities when they come up, if you know yourself, and if you fight for what you believe in, I can promise that you will live a life that is rich with meaning.

vulnerable.word_definition: capable of being wounded or hurt
vulnerable.word_example: You must be weak before the world, because love and listening weaken you. They make you  vulnerable. They break you open. And it is only when you are weak that you can truly see and acknowledge and forgive and love the weakness in others. Weakness allows you to see other humans not as enemies to defeat, but as collaborators and co-creators.

ultimate.word_definition: furthest or highest in degree or order; utmost or extreme
ultimate.word_example: So whether you’re running for president or just about to enter the workplace, sleep is the  ultimate performance-enhancing drug – and one without side effects, if you don’t count bed-head, which apparently some young people actually want, therefore it’s not a side effect, it’s a bonus feature.

cosmos.word_example: Science allows us to communicate across the seas and fly above the clouds, to cure disease and understand the  cosmos, but those same discoveries can be turned into ever more efficient killing machines.

President Obama's Speech at Hiroshima.list_detailed_description: President Obama spoke in Hiroshima, Japan on May 27, 2016. He is the first president to speak there since the United States dropped a nuclear bomb on the city to end World War II on August 6,1945. hallmark.word_example: In ten days, the world will witness a  hallmark of our democracy: the peaceful transfer of power from one freely-elected president to the next.

contentious.word_example: The work of democracy has always been hard,  contentious and sometimes bloody.

creed.word_definition: any system of principles or beliefs

demographic.word_example: A shrinking world, growing inequality;  demographic change and the specter of terrorism – these forces haven’t just tested our security and prosperity, but our democracy as well.

corrosive.word_example: But stark inequality is also  corrosive to our democratic principles.

partisanship.word_example: The rise of naked  partisanship, increasing economic and regional stratification, the splintering of our media into a channel for every taste – all this makes this great sorting seem natural, even inevitable.

automation.word_definition: the act of implementing the control of equipment
automation.word_example: It will come from the relentless pace of  automation that makes many good, middle-class jobs obsolete.

authoritarianism.word_example: For the fight against extremism and intolerance and sectarianism are of a piece with the fight against  authoritarianism and nationalist aggression. If the scope of freedom and respect for the rule of law shrinks around the world, the likelihood of war within and between nations increases...

pandemic.word_definition: an outbreak of disease that is geographically widespread
pandemic.word_example: I’ve seen our doctors and volunteers rebuild after earthquakes and stop  pandemics in their tracks.

primacy.word_definition: the state of being first in importance
primacy.word_example: It’s that spirit – a faith in reason, and enterprise, and the  primacy of right over might, that allowed us to resist the lure of fascism and tyranny during the Great Depression, and build a post-World War II order with other democracies...

President Obama's Farewell Address.list_detailed_description: President Obama delivered his farewell address on January 10, 2017. The speech detailed what President Obama holds to be the core components that make up American democracy and outlined what he considers to be the continuing threats, located both home and abroad.
